item.title: Module 2
item.description:
• **
  • Unknown if Homer was one person or multiple
    • May have inserted himself into his works as a type of self-portrait
  • The Illiad
    • Exists within 900 year space- most likely originally transcribed from oral history
  • Transcribed approx 1 century after conception
  • 16,000 lines long and composed 10 years before war between the Greeks and the Trojans.
    • The Trojan war
    • This war took place approx 4 years before the piece was written
    • We start in the middle of the war
  • Talks of the flood-almost like in Gilgamesh
    • Couple spared in the flood and tasked with repopulating the earth through throwing stones (the bones of the earth)
  • Troy is the western coast of Turkey
    • Several layers have been excavated in this region discovering cities (9)
    • Some evidence of war in this region from excavations
    • The Hittite kingdom was located near the East of the Troy - can easily make cultural references/connection
  • The Trojan war is started by the Judgement of Paris in which he chooses Aphrodite for love over two other Goddesses, Athena and Hera/ Paris seduced Helen, wife of Spartan Lord Menelaus. Menelaus seeks the aid of his brother Agamemnon.
    • The content of the poem centers around Achilles, the greatest warrior of Agamemnon’s forces
  • Angered the god Apollo by kidnapping Chryseis- the daughter of the high priest Chryses
  • Forced to give up this woman, Agamemnon takes Achilles concubine Briseis in return, angering Achilles and provoking the warrior to “sit out” the war. He will return
  • Achilles is accidentally killed
    • Tension in this poem is that of the immortality of the gods and the mortality of the humans
  • Achilles must reconcile himself to his own mortality
  • Gods have to recognize just how much they’ve become- involved and immersed in human activity
    • Gilgamesh and the Iliad have many similarities
    • The Trojan horse
  • The Odyssey
    • Multiple narratorial perspectives, Odysseus tells his story in the first person in the middle.
    • Dactylic Hexameter is a line of poetry with six metrical feet (one strong stress and two weak stresses)
    • Major spaces: The main hall of Odyseeus kingdom
  • Coming of age, growing old
  • The collateral of war
  • Wit and intellect over sheer fore
  • Arbitrary acts of the gods and the powerlessness of humanity

The Odyssey#

Books 1-8#

  • We start with summary of the whole: “He came to see / many people’s cities, where he learned their customs, / while on the sea his spirit suffered many torments” (1.3-5)]
    • Almost like a muse
  • We begin with an assembly of the gods, with Zeus and Athena speaking (Athena loves Odysseus for his cunning and his battle prowess) Zeus: “How could I forget godlike Odysseus, / pre-eminent among all mortal men for his intelligence and offerings / to the mortal gods” (1.66-68)
  • Some linkage to the Illiad
  • The gods will send Hermes, the messenger god, to Calypso, who holds Odysseus on her island (he’s been there seven years) Athena goes to Ithaca, to Odysseus’ palace where his son, Telemachus must entertain suitors to his mother (vying for her hand in marriage with Odysseus gone so long and presumed dead). Note the **hospitality **of Telemachus to the disguised goddess; hospitality is a significant theme in this text, so obsessed with feasting! Notice the contrast between Telemachus and the suitors. Notice too how the bard Phemius performs a song of Achaeans returning from Troy (but Penelope stops him from singing that “painful song” (1.276).
    • Odysseus is a poor young man
    • Hospitality is a central theme of the text and the culture as a whole
  • The idea that when aiding a stranger, you actually might be aiding a god or gods in disguise- you may be rewarded for your actions- so be kind
  • Telemachus is angry with all the suitors- Athena advises Telemachus to sail off and seek the word of his father (King Nestor in Pylos and the to Menelaus in Sparta)
    • ““If you think it’s better and would prefer / that one man’s livelihood should be consumed / without paying anything, I’ll call on / the immortal gods to see if mighty Zeus / will bring about an act of retribution” (1.319-23)”
    • “Telemachus spoke, then threw the scepter on the ground / and burst out crying” (2.52-53).
    • Wily Penelope quote about the suitors- sounds similar to her husband Odysseus
  • “you [suitors] must wait, / although you are keen for me to marry, / till I complete this cloak—for if I don’t, / my weaving would be wasted and in vain” (2.74-77) [but, after four years, she is betrayed by one of her women]
  • Female characters are shown throughout the text weaving (including Athena)- a metaphor for how the narrative of the story is being shaped and spun over time
  • Betrayed by a female servant who thus ends her resistance to the suitors (cant stop them)
  • Athena roams Ithaca in disguise as Telemachus to recruit sailors for him in order to ensure that he is able to depart in a swift manner
    • In Book 3 (omitted from your books), Telemachus will sail to Peleponnese (southern Greece) and journey by land to the city of Pylos where he will be entertained by his father’s old comrade, King Nestor. The King offers his own account of the battles at Troy and his return home to Pylos. The King will send Telemachus on, further, to Sparta to see Menelaus. Nestor’s son, Pisistratus (same name as later Athenian ruler) will accompany Telemachus.
  • Telemachus compares the Hall of Menelaus to Zeus’s kingdom- and is corrected by Minnelaus:
    • “No man alive could rival Zeus, dear boys, / with his everlasting palace and possessions” (4.87-88).
  • Meleanus grieves for Odyseus and recognizes Telemachus by his resemblance to his father
    • Helen’s and Menelaus’ account of Odysseus sneaking into Troy as a beggar and, then, the Trojan Horse: “We heard you [Helen] call. / Two of us—Diomedes and myself—were eager to get up and charge outside / or else to answer back from where we sat, in side the horse. But Odysseus stopped us—/we wished to speak, but he held us in check” (4.86-90)
    • Helen admits that she might have been drugged in Troy
    • We are reminded of the characters own mortality
  • Athena appeals to the gods to aid Odysseus, who is still trapped on the island with Calypso and has been for 7 years. Athena describes the ambush that is being set for Telemachus. Hermes goes to Calypso to tell her that Odysseus must leave the island. Further establishes the theme of mortality vs immortality

    • Odysseus sits regularly by the sea “his eyes always full of tears / because he was squandering his sweet life, mourning / for his return” (5.100-103).

EH 242 Module 3 Notes#

Introduction#

  • Publius Ovidius Virgil

  • Wrote erotic love poetry
    • The Amores
    • The Ars Amoritia
    • The Remedia Ammoris
  • Banished in 8CE by Emperor augustus- “carmen et arrow”
  • Lived out his last years in on the Black Sea
  • Far from rome
  • Books completed about the time of Ovid’s banishment
  • 15 books engaging mythological history from creation of the earth till Julius Caesar.
  • Changes to epic and myth
  • Cruelty and selfish nature of the gods
  • Language and change

Book 1#

  • Speaks of forms in different bodies
  • Bring the lengthened narrative from beginning of world

Summary#

  • Ovid invokes the gods and asks them to help with his work
  • Talks about the creation of the world
    • Similar to the creation story in the Bible
    • 4 ages follow
  • The Age of gold
    • Trust, moral goodness, fruitfulness
  • The age of Silver
    • People have to work for a living
  • The age of bronze
    • First wars but some morality persists
  • Age of Iron
    • Nothing is sacred
    • Even turning against members of your own family
    • Gods appear and witness the issues with the humans

item.title: Module 4
item.description:
Sundjata#

General plot structure#

  • The plot is divided into the following sections:
    • Paternal ancestry of Sunjata
    • Buffalo-woman tale
    • Birth and childhood of Sunjata
    • Exile of Sunjata
    • Return and war with Sumanguru
  • Nare Maghann Konate receives a hunter on his court
    • Hunter predicts that if Konate married an ugly woman, she would someday produce him a son that would someday become a great king
    • The king is already married to a woman
    • When two hunters from another kingdom present him a woman named Sogolon - the king remembers the prophecy and marries her
  • She produces a son that is unable to walk throughout his childhood
  • Sassouma jealous of the child and mother and would make fun of his inability to walk
  • Despite his physical weakness king still grants him Griot (West African storyteller)
    • Provide consolation to him
  • Death of the king occurs and his first son (Dankaram Tuman) assumes the throne despite Konate’s wishes that the prophecy be respected
    • Sundiata and his mother who had given birth to two daughters and adopted a second son from Konate’s third wife Namandje
  • Suffers scorn of new king and mother
    • Insult against Sogolon, Sundiata breaks an iron rod that he got from the blacksmith as he tries to pull himself upwards and to stand
    • Sundiata is able to walk after his father dies and his mother orders him to do
  • Sundiata is able to walk after his father dies
  • Hatred of Sassouma Berete and Dankaran Toumani Keita drove Sundiata and his family into exile
    • Neighboring kingdoms are unwilling to harbor them
  • While living in the Mema kingdom Sundiata grows as “strong as a lion”
    • Fought with a great general of the Mema people
    • Became a great warrior
    • Sogolon encouraged him to “fulfill his destiny” and return to Mali to become the king
  • Soumaoro Kante a historical leader of the Sosso people who rose to prominence after demise of Ghana empire
    • Portrayed in the epic as a cruel sorcerer king
    • Attacked the Mandinka kingdom
  • Causes Dankaran Toumani to take flight in fear
    • Soumaoro has conquered nine kingdoms in the former Ghana empire
  • Oppressed Mandinka people then sent for the exiled Sundiata
  • Forges a coalition of neighboring small kingdoms
    • Sundiata wages a war against the Sosso
  • Crowned as the Mansa (“King of Kings”)
  • First ruler of the Mali empire
  • Set about organizing the empire
    • Presenting Gbara of nobles and notables at his coronation with oral constitution
    • Model for governance that persists into the future

Africa’s as the Cradle of Civilization#

  • Africas great drift valley
    • Where the story of humanity likely begins
  • Evidence that the anatomically modern humans emerged in the continent of Africa.
    • Belief that humans began walking on the earth much earlier than possible
    • Likely to find more evidence as time goes on
    • We are all likely descended from African American ancestors - common ancestors in Africa
    • Around 80000-50000 years ago humans began to spread out through the rest of the world
    • Caves in Africa show the first signs of Human artistic expression on the walls
    • Face paintings sometimes used to communicate/identify
  • 10000 years human began to breed animals and eventually start going towards domestication
  • Eventually move to the area near the source of a Nile and become the ancestors of Humans

Webcast 1#

African Empires#

  • Umayyad caliphate controls much of upper Africa and the Middle East
  • African Empries
    • Ghana (Wagadou) (8th-11th century)
    • Al Moravids (11th-12th century)
    • Al Mohads (1147-ealy 13th century)
    • Mali (early-13th century)

Medieval West Africa- Mali Empire#

  • This is the context for the story
  • Rise of the Sossos (Kaniaga) and Sousaomo Kante Sosso (sorcerer king in the story)
  • Revolt against Sossos including Mali- Plot of story
  • Battle of Krinia (1235)- Sundiata defeats the Sossos and unifies Mali Kings
  • First sub-saharan people to accept Islam
  • Traders begin to have prayers in thier towns
  • Set up in the Sharia system
  • King employs Muslim interpreters
  • City contains 12 mosques- 1 mosque for congressional prayers
    • Designed a mosque featuring an inner court with the exact dimensions of Kabba in Mecca
    • Became a center of education
    • Mosque sees visitors almost constantly
    • Temple creates a large library of texts-many of which survive to today
    • Also accumulated navigational maps from explorers.
    • The Mali empire was one of the largest in the world at the time
  • King was Maza Abu Boukahri
  • Studied at St Corie univesity
    • Read a text saying that the Atlantic ocean was not the edge of the world and then he studied ocean currents
  • Perform an expedition with 200 ships amply stocked for the expedition
    • Captain told him of success and would build upwards of 2000
  • In 1311 hands over the government and title of Mansour to his brother
    • Fufill dream of sailing across the Atlantic
      • Beleived that they took off but likely did not make
      • Christopher columbus may not have been the first person to cross the ocean
        • Unknown if they made it back
  • Aby Boukhari interested in extending borders of the empire to east toward Cairo
  • Caputred neighboring cities in order to expand the empire
  • Richest man in history (at the time)- Mansa Musa

Griots#

  • 20th century girot Mamodou Kouyate provides this version of the Suniata
  • “The future springs from the past”
  • Griots’ importance to political as “memory”
  • Haji pilgramages
    • Ambulate the Kabba
  • Many versions of the story
  • “Living memory” books

Important Themes#

- Third epic
- Hunting and gathering
  • Hunters songs
  • Appalachia songs
  • Blues songs

Webcast 2 (4-21)#

“l am a hunter chasing game and come from Sangaran…” (4) “The hunters of Sandaran are the best soothsayers” (4) “The left hand is the hand of evil” (5) “Mali is about to emerge from the night” (5)

item.title: Part 1
item.description:
Chapter 1#

  • Sound beings with the vibration of an object
    • Sound transmitted by a medium
  • Music is part of the world of sound

Pitch: Highness or Lowness of Sound#

  • Pitch → Highness or lowness of a sound
  • Sound that has a definite pitch is called a tone
    • Has a specific frequency
    • Vibrations of a tone are regular and reach the ear at regular intervals
    • Tones will sound different with different pitches
  • Interval of an octave - interval between first and last tones of the scale
    • Octave has seven different pitched before arriving at the high note which duplicates the first one
    • 7 tones on the keyboard
    • Added 12 tones are duplicated in higher and lower octaves
  • Distance is known as the pitch range
  • Most music is based on definite pitches

Dynamics#

  • Dynamics → Degrees of loudness or softness are known as
    • Loudness or softness affects the type of the sound
  • Italian terms indicate dynamics
  • Ways to indicate dynamical changes
  • Not super precise
    • Tone has a dynamic level - in relation to other tones around the instrument or vocal

Tone Color#

  • Tone color or Timbre descriptions
    • Bright
    • Dark
    • Brilliant
    • Mellow
    • Rich
  • Even though instruments might sound the same, the sound that the instrument creates will likely vary

Chapter 2#

Voices#

  • Singing demands a greater control of pitch and volume
  • Range of singers voice depends on training and physical makeup
  • Professionals usually have a vocal range of about 2 octaves

Musical Instruments#

  • Any mechanism other than a voice that produce musical sounds

item.title: Part 2
item.description:
Chapter 11- Music in the Middle Ages#

  • Most important musicians were priests and worked for the church
    • Liturgical singing
    • Boys received music education in schools associated with churches and cathedrals
  • Most medieval was vocal- musicians also performed on a wide variety of instruments
    • “pronouncing the words of the Holy spirit”
  • Instruments incorporated into church music after 1800
  • We don’t know much about how medieval music sounded- most of the instruments have been destroyed

Gregorian Chant#

  • Official music of the Roman Catholic church for over 1000 years
  • Designed to enhance specific parts of religious services
  • Conveys calm, otherworldly quality
    • Flexible rhythm, no meter, little sense of beat
    • Almost an improvisational character, due to the lack of beat and flexible
  • Named after Pope Gregory 1= 590-604
  • Originally passed down through oral tradition, later notated
  • Composers completely unknown

The Church Modes#

  • Gregorian chant results partly from unfamiliar scales
    • “Church modes”
  • Same as major and minor scales, but half steps are different

Secular music in the Middle Ages#

  • Secular music → Music outside of the church
    • 13th century
    • Dance in wooded places, parties, etc.

Troubadour and Trouvere Song#

  • Active in courts of the nobility and in towns during the 12th and 13th centuries
    • Troubadours- Live in southern France and write poems in the Provencal language
    • Trouveres- Flourish in northern France and write in Old French
  • Mostly about courtly/idealized love for the idea noble lady
  • Different backgrounds- some nobles, some have modest backgrounds
  • Notated as single melodic lines
    • Monophonic texture

Minstrels#

  • Entertained in castles, public places, etc.
    • Perform music, told stories
  • Lowest social level with no civil rights
  • Not many found steady work
  • Important source of info because there were no newspapers

The Development of Polyphony: Organum#

  • Type of polyphony
  • Original music in this time had a single melodic line
  • Monks in monasteries begin to add a second melodic line to Gregorian chant
    • Originally improvised
  • Duplication of original melody at diff pitch
    • Developed a melodic curve of its own
  • 1100- not restricted to a note against not style
  • Lines could differ rhythmically as melodically

School of Notre Dame: Measured Rhythm#

  • 1150- Paris becomes a center of polyphonic music
    • Measured rhythm - definite time values and clearly defined meter
    • Notation describes precise rhythm and pitches
    • By modern standards, medieval polyphony is hollow and thin
  • Lack of triads
    • 2 intervals of a third

14th Century Music: The “New Art” in France#

  • ars nova
  • Secular music becomes more important than sacred music
  • Composer could specify any rhythmic pattern
    • Beats can be subdivision
    • Syncopation becomes important
  • Leonin and Perotin - measured rhythm, definite time values and rhythms
    • Notation indicated precise rhythms as well as pitches

Guillaume de Machaut#

  • Born in French province of Champagne
  • Spent much of his life in the service of many royal families
  • Traveled to many courts and presented his music to various royals
  • Music consists mostly of love songs
  • Mass Ordinary -texts that remain the same from day to day throughout a church year

Chapter 2: Music in the Renaissance#

  • 1450-1600
  • Renaissance idea of the “universal man”
  • Church remains an important patron of music but musical activity gradually shifts to the courts
    • Church choirs grow in size
    • People in positions of power compete for the finest composers and musicians

Characteristics of Renaissance Music#

Words and Music#

  • Vocal music more important than instrumental music
    • Humanistic interest in language vocal music
  • Close relationship between words and music
    • “Word painting” → Musical depiction of specific words
    • Emotion expressed in a moderate, balanced way, no extreme contrasts of dynamics

Texture#

  • Renaissance music is chiefly polyphonic
    • Imitation among the voices is common
    • Homophonic texture with successions of chords is also used
  • Sounds much fuller than medieval music
  • Did not need instrumental accompaniment

Rhythm and Melody#

  • Gentle flow than a defined beat
  • Each singer must maintain an individual rhythm

Sacred Music in the Renaissance#

  • Motet and the mass are the two forms of Renaissance music
    • Motet
  • Polyphonic choral work set to a sacred Latin text
    • Mass
  • Polyphonic choral composition made up of five sections

Josquin Desprez and the Renaissance market#

  • Compositions have masses, motes, and secular vocal pieces
  • Ave Maria
    • Opening uses polyphonic imitation
    • Short melodic phrase is presented by a soprano voice and then imitated in turn by the alto, tenor, and bass
    • Motet- 2,3 or 4 voices can be heard at the same time
  • Duets between high voices imitated by the lower parts
  • Almost homophonic at times

Palestrina and the Renaissance Mass#

  • Palestrina music includes 104 and 450 sacred works
  • 1500s and Catholic church was challenged and questioned by the Protestants
  • Jesuit order founded to strengthen the church
  • Convening of the council of Tent considers questions of dogma and organization
    • Church music should be composed to inspire religious contemplation
  • Palestrina’s emphasis works reflect an emphasis on more spiritual music

Pope Marcellus Mass#

  • Kyrie - rich polyphonic texture
    • Curved melody
    • Upward leaps balanced by downward steps

Secular Music in the Renaissance#

Vocal Music#

  • Secular music becomes increasingly popular
  • Development of music printing helps to increase the spread of music
    • Music becomes an important leisure activity
  • Renaissance secular music was written for groups of solo voices and for solo voice with the accompaniment of one or more instruments
  • Madrigal - a piece for several solo voices set to a short poem, usually about love
    • Originated during a creative explosion in Italy around 1520
    • Uses word painting and unusual harmonies more often

Thomas Weelkes#

  • Written to Honor Queen Elizabeth

Renaissance Lute Song#

  • Lute is a plucked string instrument
  • Lute song cultivated from the late 1590s to the 1620s
    • Mostly homophonic in texture

John Dowland#

  • “Flow my Tears”
    • ABC section repeated - AA BB CC
    • Song about hopelessness but has uplifting moments

Instrumental Music#

  • Becomes more important during the Renaissance
    • Able to be free from vocal music in the 16th century
    • Instrumental music intended for dancing
  • Renaissance musicians distinguished between loud and soft instruments

Michael Praetorius#

  • Passamezzo and Galliard pair contrasting court dances and triple meter

item.title: Part 4
item.description:
Romanticism in Music#

  • About 1820-1900
  • Franz Schubert, Robert Schumann, Clara Wieck Schumann, Hendel, Dvorak, etc.
  • Continued to use the musical forms of the classical era
    • Emotional intensity was already present in Classical work
  • Romantic music usually have a greater range of tone color, dynamics and pitch
    • Harmonic vocabulary is broader
  • More emphasis on colorful, unstable chords
  • Linked more closely to other arts- literature

Characteristics of Romantic Music#

Individuality of Style#

  • Expression of the individual and the individuality of self
  • Tchaikovsky, Chopin, Schumann were some of the pioneers of this style

Expressive Aims and Subjects#

  • Flamboyance and intimacy, unpredictability, melancholy, rapture and longing
    • Glorification of Romantic love
    • Fantastic and Diabolical
  • Dream of a Witches’ sabbath
  • All aspects of Nature attracted Romantic musicians
  • Subjects drawn from the Middle Ages and Shakespeare

Nationalism and Exoticism#

  • Composers create music that express a National Identity
  • Exoticism → Composers drawing on colorful materials from foreign lands

Program Music#

  • Program Music → Instrumental music associated with a story, poem or idea
    • Can represent the emotions, characters, and events of a particular story. can evoke the sounds and motion of nature
    • Romeo and Juliet - Tchaikovsky
  • Music matches the mood of the scene

Expressive Tone Color#

  • Rich and sensuous sound
    • Timbre is extremely important
    • Romantic orchestra is larger and more varied in tone color than the classical orchestra
  • 100 ish people
  • 20-60 in classical
    • Brass, Woodwind, Percussion take on a more active role
  • Brass
    • Trombones, Trumpets, etc
  • Woodwind
    • Bass Clarinet
    • English horn
    • Piccolo
  • Composers want to blend and combine tone colors
  • Piano vastly improved during the 1820s and 1830s
    • Piano tone became more “singing”
    • Range extended
    • Pianist could produce more sound due to a larger instrument
    • Damper pedal allowed for blend of tones from all registers of the piano

Colorful Harmony#

  • Explored new chords/existing chords
  • Emphasized greater emotional intensity, rich, colorful and complex harmonies
  • Chromatic harmony → Uses chords containing tones not found in the prevailing major or minor scale
    • Chromatic scale
    • Add color and motion to romantic music

Expanded Range of Dynamics, Pitch, Tempo#

  • Sharp contrasts between dynamics
    • ffff, pppp, etc.
    • More expressiveness- use crescendos, etc
    • Often accompanied by changes in pace

Form: Miniature and Monumental#

  • Thematic transformation - change the melody as it returns later in a piece by changing dynamics, etc.
  • Different movements of a romantic work can be linked together through transitional passages

Romantic Composers and Their Public#

  • Composers role in society changed greatly during the time of Beethoven
    • Part of the musicians job had been the composition of works for a specific occasion and audience
    • Bach wrote cantatas for weekly church services
    • One of the first musicians to work freelance
  • This image of Beethoven inspired romantic writers
  • Romantic composers were interested in pleasing those around them and being judged fairly by posterity
    • Free artists by necessity rather than choice
  • Many aristocrats could not afford to have court musicians
  • Romantic composers wrote primarily for a middle class audience
    • Citizens expanded dramatically and people want to hear music
  • First half of the nineteenth century witnessed the founding of music conservatories throughout Europe
    • Captured by virtuosity
  • Private music making also increased during the romantic era
    • Piano becomes a fixture in middle class homes
  • Romantic composers came from the social class that was their main audience
  • It was difficult for children to make a living through music
    • Most composers were forced to work at many areas at work

Sonata Form#

  • Sonata form → Refers to the form of a single movement

    • Exposition → Themes are presented

item.title: Part 5
item.description:
Chapter 5#

The Art song (lied)#

  • Art sing is a composition for solo voice and piano
    • Accompaniment is a integral part of the composers concept
  • Original meant to be sung at home, not at concert halls
  • Poetry and music are fused in the art song - flourished with increasing amount of romantic poetry
  • Song composers would interpret or translate a poem into musical form

Song Forms#

  • Strophic form makes a song easy to remember and is used in almost all folk songs
    • Repeats the same music in each stanza
  • Through composed forms writes new music for each stanza
    • Used to reflect poems changing moods

The Song Cycle#

  • Romantic songs are usually grouped in a set or, song cycle
    • Sometimes unified by a story line that runs through poems or by musical ideas that link the songs

Franz Schubert#

  • 1797-1828
  • Earliest master of the Romantic art song
  • Never held an official position- made his income entirely through composition
  • Schubert was born in Vienna, son of a schoolmaster
  • Composed a large number of works in his late teenage years
  • Wrote Gretchen am Spindale and The Erlking
  • Composed close to 200 works per year
  • Most of his works were designed to be performed for the middle class
  • Did not mingle with the aristocracy
  • Died in 1828 at the age of 31

Schubert’s Music#

  • Schubert composed over 600 works
  • The melodies of his songs have a larger variety of moods and types.
    • Some folklike tunes to complex lines that suggest impassioned speech
  • Schubert’s harmonies and dissonances provide some poetic moments in music
  • Spirit of song permeates Schubert’s music too
    • Symphonies and chamber works have longer lyrical melodies
  • Most of his famous Trout Quintet in A minor
  • Most of the symphonies and chamber works have long, lyrical melodies which are sometimes comparable in power and intensity to those his idol
  • Erlking is a great example of musical romanticism
    • Piano part builds the excitement of the work
    • Also the piano parts unifies the episodes of the song and suggests the horse’s gallop
  • Schubert varies the music makes one signer sound like several characters in a miniature drama

Robert Schumann#

  • 1810-1856
  • His works are autobiographical and usually have descriptive titles, texts, or programs
  • Born in Germany and studied law at Leipzig university
    • Devoted most of his time to music
  • Had an issue with his hand that sometimes hampered his ability to play music

Schumann’s Music#

  • Composed many art songs in 1840

Clara Wieck Schumann#

  • Leading concert pianists of the nineteenth century
  • 1819-1896
  • Premiered many works by her husband, Robert Schumann and by Johannes Brahms

  • Continued to concertize and compose though on a reduced scale while caring for seven children

Fredric Chopin#

  • 1810-1849
  • Wrote almost exclusively for the piano
  • Son of a Polish mother and French father and was brought up in Warsaw
  • At 21 moved to Paris which was the center of romanticism and the artistic capital of Europe
    • Gained access to aristocratic salons
    • Preferred salons to concert halls - conceived short pieces such as the nocturnes, preludes and waltzes
  • Died of tuberculosis at 39 years old

Chopin’s Music#

  • Personal and original styles
  • Miniatures- Most of his pieces evoked a variety of moods and are elegant, peaceful and melodic
    • His melodic gift creates the illusion that the piano is signing
  • Composed Nocturne in E flat major, Op 9, No 2 when he was around 20
    • Slow, lyrical composition for piano
    • Opens with a Legato melody containing graceful upward leaps, which become more wide as the line unfolds
    • Melody occurs three times throughout the piece
    • Includes a subordinate melody that is played with slight fluctuations in the tempo
    • Widely spaced notes in the accompaniment
  • Rev Etude in C minor
    • May have been inspired by the Russian takeover of Warsaw in 1831
    • Speed and endurance is developed in the Pianists left hand, which plays rapid passages throughout
    • A A’ Form
    • High dissonant chords and downward rushing passages lead to the main melody

Franz Liszt#

  • 1811-1886
  • During the 1840s performed superhuman feats on the piano
    • Overwhelms the European public
    • Impressing musicians and the concertgoing public
  • Born in Hungary
    • Studied in Vienna at age 11, met Schubert and Beethoven
    • Moved to Paris in teens and twenties
    • Met Pagani, a violinists, and resolved to become greater at the piano, came back to stage life a couple of years later as a great pianist
  • Composed the Transcendental Etudes and made Piano transcriptions of Paganins violin pieces
  • At 36 became a court conductor in Wien mar to establish himself as a serious composer
    • Provided free piano education to Gifted individuals
  • Became president of the New Academy of Music

Liszt’s Music#

  • Created the Symphonic poem- a one movement orchestral composition based to some extent on literary or pectoral ideas

Felix Mendelson#
